unnormalised: The Indian stock market saw some volatility today, bhai! The Sensex initially jumped 250 points in early trading, fueled by positive global cues. Experts are saying it’s mostly due to FII inflows. But, *thoda* (a little) profit booking led to it closing almost flat, around 66,500. Not a major dip, but *sambhal ke rehna* (be careful)!
normalised: The Indian stock market saw some volatility today, brother! The Sensex initially jumped two hundred and fifty points in early trading, fueled by positive global cues. Experts are saying it is mostly due to F-I-I inflows. But, a little profit booking led to it closing almost flat, around sixty six thousand five hundred. Not a major dip, but be careful!

unnormalised: Talk about individual stocks, Reliance ended slightly higher after announcing its quarterly results, while Tata Motors took a hit. Apparently, some investors are worried about rising raw material costs, but their EV sales are still looking good. ICICI Bank saw a bit of movement as well after rumors about a possible stake sale, but it looks like just *afwah* (rumour) for now. Analysts predict a bullish trend for next week *agar* (if) the global markets remain stable.
normalised: Talk about individual stocks, Reliance ended slightly higher after announcing its quarterly results, while Tata Motors took a hit. Apparently, some investors are worried about rising raw material costs, but their E-V sales are still looking good. I-C-I-C-I Bank saw a bit of movement as well after rumors about a possible stake sale, but it looks like just rumour for now. Analysts predict a bullish trend for next week if the global markets remain stable.

unnormalised: Remember, invest *soch samajh ke* (thoughtfully)! Don't just follow tips from your uncle. Consult a SEBI-registered advisor, and do your own research. And if you're a newbie, maybe start with mutual funds or SIPs *pehle* (first). Remember, *jaldi ka kaam shaitan ka* (haste makes waste), especially when your hard-earned ₹ is involved! Good luck, investors!
normalised: Remember, invest thoughtfully! Do not just follow tips from your uncle. Consult a S-E-B-I-registered advisor, and do your own research. And if you are a newbie, maybe start with mutual funds or S-I-P-s first. Remember, haste makes waste, especially when your hard-earned rupee is involved! Good luck, investors!
